title: Setting Up The Winter Chicken Coop Part 2 and Setting Up The Waterer

tasks.task: Assembling roosting poles and waterer for chickens and ducks
subtasks: Planning roost pole heights and spacing
Securing roosting poles to the roof
Setting up an automatic waterer using a 55-gallon drum
Preparing the chicken coop for new inhabitants
Documenting the process and engaging with the audience

tasks.task: Setting up coop facilities, which includes:
MAINTASK: Launching video content and community engagement.
Set up the chicken coop with roosting poles, waterer, and prepare for animal introduction.
Document the setup and engage with community.
Assemble roosting poles and waterer in chicken coop
subtasks: Plan roost pole positions, spacing, and height (15 inches apart, 16 inches off ground)
Drill holes and secure roosting poles to the roof
Set up automatic waterer using a 55-gallon drum (clean drum, elevate, adjust float)

tasks.task: Prepare chicken coop for occupants
subtasks: Place hay in the coop for chickens to use
Expose the area to chickens and ducks for them to explore

tasks.task: place the whole MAINTASK as "Assemble roosting poles, waterer, and prepare coop," but splitting into multiple subtasks. Since there are three major things mentioned: roost poles, waterer, and introducing the animals, but the transcript ends before that. Hmm. Alternatively, because the actual coop preparation (hay, etc.) is a small part, maybe it's considered part of making the coop habitable.
Set up chicken coop with roosting poles, waterer, and prepare for use

MAINTASK for the video would be the setup, and adding interaction as a separate MAINTASK if that's going to happen. But given the transcript description is about the setup process, it's probably not necessary. Therefore, we can put in tasks based on what's shown. So perhaps:
Assemble roosting poles, waterer, and prepare coop for new chickens and ducks

But since the transcript ends just before bringing the animals in, of course, the tasks would need to end with that. So it's a bit of a cliffhanger. So maybe the subtask for introducing the animals is implicit. Hmm. Alternatively, split the MAINTASKs here.
one for the setup and another for bringing in the animals. But since the transcript cuts off just after the mention of doing that, perhaps best to leave it as one MAINTASK with all subtasks covered.
Alternatively, split the learning video from the current step the performer is at. But given the OP asks for tasks based on the transcript, let's go with one MAINTASK with all subtasks.
Complete chicken coop set actions

Prepare coop for animals (hay and welcoming)
planning, execution, and introduce.

Prepare the coop for occupants

But as the transcript ends before Step 2 in MAINTASK2, I think we can't include that. So maybe only one MAINTASK.
Assemble roosting poles, automatic waterer, and prepare the coop for animals

Therefore, the best option seems to have the roost pole setup, waterer installed, and hay prepared as part of the MAINTASK focusing on the setup. The intended next step is introducing the animals, but since it's not shown, we probably leave that out of the tasks.

installation of roosting poles and waterer, and then preparation for the animals, but since the transcript only mentions thoughts about introducing the animals, not the actual task, we cannot include that.

So here, he's wanting to bring the chickens and ducks in. Since this is described as the "fun part", perhaps actually assembling, introducing the animals, and observing is one continuous task. That would make it one MAINTASK.
Plan and execute video content for staging a new chicken coop
Stage a chicken coop with roosting poles and an automatic waterer
Assemble roosting poles, install waterer, and prepare bedding
Set up roosting poles, waterer, and bedding for the chicken coop
Putting it all together, the final answer would list four subtasks under one MAINTASK, and I think that's a good approach.
Set up roosting poles, waterer, and bedding for the new chicken coop
